hook.text: You contracted to buy a unique painting. The seller refuses. Money can't replace it. The court orders delivery.

buildup.text: Specific performance is an equitable remedy: a court order compelling the breaching party to do what they promised.

discovery.text: It's only granted when monetary damages are inadequateâ€”typically for unique items, land, or rare goods.

twist.text: Courts almost never order specific performance for personal services. Forcing someone to work raises freedom concerns.

climax.text: Land contracts are the classic case. Every parcel is legally unique, so money is never a perfect substitute.

punchline.text: When money isn't enough, courts order action.

quiz.question: When do courts typically grant specific performance?
options: When the subject is unique and damages are inadequate
